persons.name: AlessandroVolta
persons.description: Professor of experimental physics at the University of Pavia. At the end of the eighteenth century he Invented the Voltaic pile which produced electric current and which Davy shortly dubbed the battery. Davy described meeting him in 1814 in notebook 14/I, p.38. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: AnthonyCarlisle
persons.description: London surgeon and anatomist. FRSL.

persons.name: WilliamNicholson
persons.description: Founding editor of A Journal of Natural Philosophy, Chemistry, and the Arts (1797-1814) where Davy published some of his early papers. Part of the Godwin circle.

persons.name: LuigiGalvani
persons.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him to refer to the generation of electric current by chemical action.

works.name: A Journal of Natural Philosophy, Chemistry, and the Arts
works.author: Humphry Davy

persons.name: ThomasBeddoes
persons.description: A politically radical (Jacobin) chemist and physician who in the 1790s established the Medical Pneumatic Institution in Bristol to investigate the physiological and possible curative effects of all the gases discovered during the eighteenth century. Between late 1798 and early 1801 he employed Davy as Superintendent of the Institution.

persons.name: ThomasBeddoes
persons.description: A politically radical (Jacobin) chemist and physician who in the 1790s established the Medical Pneumatic Institution in Bristol to investigate the physiological and possible curative effects of all the gases discovered during the eighteenth century. Between late 1798 and early 1801 he employed Davy as Superintendent of the Institution.

persons.name: WilliamHenry
persons.description: Manchester physician and chemist, whose Elements of Experimental Chemistry went through eleven editions. FRSL.

persons.name: LuigiGalvani
persons.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him to refer to the generation of electric current by chemical action.

persons.name: JosephPriestley
persons.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

persons.name: Carl FriedrichWenzel
persons.description: German chemist and metallurgist

persons.name: RichardKirwan
persons.description: Irish chemist, mineralogist and geologist who accused fellow geologist, James Hutton, of atheism following publication of his Theory of the Earth (1788). FRSL

persons.name: JosephPriestley
persons.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

persons.name: JosephPriestley
persons.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

persons.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
persons.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: LuigiGalvani
persons.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him to refer to the generation of electric current by chemical action.

persons.name: JohnKing
persons.description: Nicholas Johann Koenig, Bristol-based surgeon, painter and linguist, originally from Bern, Switzerland. A friend of Davy's in Bristol, King took his position at the Medical Pneumatic Institute after Davy left for London in 1801. King married Emmeline Edgeworth in 1803.

persons.name: PatrickDwyer
persons.description: Assisted Davy during his research into the physiological effects of nitrous oxide at the Medical Pneumatic Intitution.

persons.name: JosephPriestley
persons.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

persons.name: WilliamWordsworth
persons.description: English poet who, with Samuel Taylor Coleridge, published Lyrical Ballads. Davy contributed to seeing the second edition (1800) through the press in Bristol. Poet Laureate from 1843.

persons.name: HenryCavendish
persons.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

places.name: River Severn
places.description: At 220 miles long, the longest river in Great Britain.

persons.name: WilliamCruikshank
persons.description: FRS. Scottish military surgeon and assistant to the Professor of Chemistry at the Royal Military Academy, Woolwich. He designed the trough battery.

persons.name: WilliamNicholson
persons.description: Founding editor of A Journal of Natural Philosophy, Chemistry, and the Arts (1797-1814) where Davy published some of his early papers. Part of the Godwin circle.
